G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time for these minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (to the extent applicable); and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions, including G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20 (to the extent a.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time for these minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (to the extent applicable); and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions, including G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time for these minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (to the extent applicable); and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions, including G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28 (1).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting‑time order must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting‑time order must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on the ‘cause shown’/best‑interests standard when parents share joint legal and physical custody. It does not articulate the general Massachusetts standard for modification of custody or parenting‑time orders as requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) best interests of the child. The only reference to ‘changed circumstances’ is in a quotation from the ALI Principles, not as a statement of Massachusetts law governing modification generally.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting‑time order must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion is focused on statutory interpretation of G. L. c. 209C, the mother’s sole legal custody prior to adjudication of paternity, and the inapplicability of the Yannas ‘removal’ analysis. It discusses custody and visitation standards generally and references best interests and stability, but it does not articulate or apply the two‑part standard that a party seeking modification must show (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification is in the child’s best interests. There is no discussion of the ‘material and substantial change’ requirement or of modification doctrine as such, so the case does not meaningfully support the claimed proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ('If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement…')."

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal decisions under the custody statute, the touchstone is whether removal is in the “best interests of the child,” and reiterates that the best interests of the children remain the “paramount concern.” Although the context is a removal/relocation dispute and not a generic custody standard section, the court’s language is broadly framed and clearly treats best interests as the controlling consideration in custody-related determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined…. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states, in its discussion of removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, that even under the ‘real advantage’ standard, the best interests of the child remain the paramount concern. Although the case focuses on relocation and modification of custody, it clearly affirms that in such determinations the child’s best interests are the controlling consideration, which aligns with the proposition cited.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A parent’s request to relocate with a child from the Commonwealth must be ‘grounded on the “realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern….’”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child.

M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).proposition: A material change in a parent’s work schedule, particularly one that interferes with the parent’s ability to exercise ordered parenting time and provide appropriate supervision, may constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion is a child-support case focused on income equalization, application of the Massachusetts Child Support Guidelines, and imputation of income. It does not address modification of custody or parenting time, nor does it discuss changes in a parent’s work schedule or supervision as a basis for modification. Because the decision is silent on material and substantial change in circumstances grounded in work-schedule changes, it does not support the stated proposition.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).relevant_excerpt: On remand, the judge is not required to revisit the issue of the father’s income at the time of trial, but should consider whether the circumstances have materially changed since the date of the judgment before us, and should base any award of child support on the parties’ current incomes.

M.P.M. v. F.M., 442 Mass. 522 (2004).proposition: A material change in a parent’s work schedule, particularly one that interferes with the parent’s ability to exercise ordered parenting time and provide appropriate supervision, may constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification.
M.P.M. v. F.M., 442 Mass. 522 (2004).support_reasoning: The case is about whether a nonbiological, nonadoptive former partner can be obligated to pay child support based on an implied contract and the equity powers of the Probate and Family Court. It does not address modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order, nor material changes in circumstances such as work-schedule changes. The opinion instead holds that, absent statutory parent status, a nonparent has no duty to support and that courts cannot create such an obligation in equity, so it provides no authority for the proposition about work-schedule changes justifying modification.
M.P.M. v. F.M., 442 Mass. 522 (2004).relevant_excerpt:
Because the defendant is not a parent under any of the statutory provisions enacted to establish parenthood, she has no duty to support the child financially, and she may not be ordered to pay child support.

Because nonparents have no duty to pay child support absent a statutory duty, equity does not provide a remedy in this case. “It is a maxim that equity follows the law as declared by a statute.” ... Equitable principles cannot be used to create a duty to pay child support where the law does not recognize a legally cognizable parent-child relationship.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that instability, frequent last‑minute changes, and inadequate supervision can adversely affect children and justify revisiting parenting time.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize the importance of stability and warns that unnecessary disruption of a child’s living arrangements can be harmful, but it does not address "frequent last‑minute changes" or "inadequate supervision" nor does it discuss revisiting or modifying parenting time on those grounds. The case is about how to structure an initial (or effectively initial) custody/visitation order under the best-interests standard, not about modifying parenting time due to instability or supervision problems. Thus it only partially overlaps on the general theme of stability and does not squarely support the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that instability, frequent last‑minute changes, and inadequate supervision can adversely affect children and justify revisiting parenting time.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the impact of domestic violence on children and the need for explicit findings about that impact when determining custody and shared custody. It does not discuss instability, last‑minute changes, or inadequate supervision as independent factors that adversely affect children or as grounds to revisit parenting time. The remand concerns failure to address domestic violence, not parenting‑time instability or supervision issues, so the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31 (1).proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, courts consider, among other factors, the child’s welfare, stability, emotional development, and the ability of each parent to provide a safe and consistent home environment.

Morgan v. Morgan, 402 Mass. 123, 127 (19.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, courts consider, among other factors, the child’s welfare, stability, emotional development, and the ability of each parent to provide a safe and consistent home environment.
Morgan v. Morgan, 402 Mass. 123, 127 (19.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Morgan v. Morgan at all, but Pobieglo v. Monsanto (a toxic exposure/statute of limitations case). It deals with application of the discovery rule to wrongful death and survival actions, not with child custody or best-interest-of-the-child factors such as welfare, stability, emotional development, or parenting capacity. Therefore, this opinion does not address, much less support, the claimed proposition about best interests of the child.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. at 544\u201.proposition: Where a previous order was appropriate when entered, but subsequent developments have rendered its application inconsistent with the child’s best interests, the Court has both the authority and the obligation to modify the order.

Champigny v. Champigny, 70 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Champigny v. Champigny, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 111, 115‑16 (2007)
Champigny v. Champigny, 70 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Where a previous order was appropriate when entered, but subsequent developments have rendered its application inconsistent with the child’s best interests, the Court has both the authority and the obligation to modify the order.
Champigny v. Champigny, 70 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal convictions for disorderly conduct and carrying a dangerous weapon and analyzes sufficiency of the evidence and statutory elements. It does not address child custody, prior court orders, modification standards, or the court’s authority or obligation to modify an order based on changed circumstances. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the claimed best‑interests/modification proposition.
Champigny v. Champigny, 70 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The provided text contains no discussion of modification of prior orders, changed circumstances, or the best interests of a child; it is limited to analysis of G. L. c. 272, § 53 and G. L. c. 269, § 10(b) in the context of a criminal conviction.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Massachusetts law also authorizes the Court to modify parenting time to impose reasonable conditions designed to protect the children and ensure that parenting time occurs only when a parent is able to provide appropriate supervision and care.

Keefe v. Keefe, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (.raw_text: Keefe v. Keefe, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (2011) (Rule 1:28 decision)
Keefe v. Keefe, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (.proposition: Massachusetts law also authorizes the Court to modify parenting time to impose reasonable conditions designed to protect the children and ensure that parenting time occurs only when a parent is able to provide appropriate supervision and care.
Keefe v. Keefe, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (.support_reasoning: The text provided for this Rule 1:28 decision (Kathleen Buduo’s Case) is extremely limited and indicates only that it is a workers’ compensation matter with the reviewing board’s decision affirmed. It does not concern parenting time, custody, or conditions on visitation, and therefore cannot serve as authority for the proposition about modifying parenting time to protect children and ensure appropriate supervision and care. The citation appears to be either erroneous or inapposite to the stated proposition.
Keefe v. Keefe, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (.relevant_excerpt:
Decision Pursuant to Rule 1:28.
Decision of reviewing board affirmed.

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704, 712‑13 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: Massachusetts law also authorizes the Court to modify parenting time to impose reasonable conditions designed to protect the children and ensure that parenting time occurs only when a parent is able to provide appropriate supervision and care.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The SJC explains that under G.L. c. 119, § 26, a judge may not only commit children to the Department but also must provide guidance regarding placement and visitation, and it emphasizes that the department’s otherwise broad discretion over visitation and placement is subject to court direction. The court specifically states that, in a care and protection case like this where family relationships and visitation have been significant, the judge must include directions about continued visitation or make findings justifying limiting it. This necessarily recognizes judicial authority to shape and condition contact/parenting time to protect the children’s best interests and ensure appropriate care.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: Although a simple commitment order is all that is required by G. L. c. 119, § 26, and the applicable regulation of the department…in this case, the judge should have given the department some guidance regarding the ultimate placement of the children and visitation by family members…When the department is granted permanent custody of a child, it has virtually free rein…Even if the separation of Mary from her sisters and grandparents is ultimately found to be in her best interests, some direction from the judge regarding continued visitation is required…[T]he judge must include in his order some direction to the department that visitation shall continue or make findings that support his conclusion if he believes it should not.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844\u20114.proposition: The Court may also consider the extent to which a parent actually exercises parenting time as ordered and whether their conduct promotes the children’s welfare and continuity of care.

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.proposition: The Court may also consider the extent to which a parent actually exercises parenting time as ordered and whether their conduct promotes the children’s welfare and continuity of care.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about SSDI-dependent benefits, attachment for support/college expenses, and the standards for modifying legal custody. While it references the need to weigh all relevant factors in determining a child’s best interests, it does not discuss or apply any analysis concerning the extent to which a parent actually exercises parenting time as ordered, nor continuity of care in the context of parenting time. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.relevant_excerpt: "However, we shall not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981), citing Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 556 n.5 (1980). See King, supra, and cases cited. ... [T]he judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings based on evidence within the record’ that awarding sole legal custody of the minor child to the defendant was in the best interests of the child."

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: Find that the requested modifications are in the best interests of the minor children, Liam and Ava Turner, under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31 and the applicable case law cited herein.
